description: Immunisation protects children against some of the most dangerous diseases of childhood.
title: Immunisation protects children against some of the most dangerous diseases of childhood
content:
All children, including children with disabilities, must be vaccinated according to the schedule established by the Ministry of Health.


A child who is not immunised with the proper vaccinations, dosage and according to schedule will have little or no protection against the following diseases, some of which can kill: 

 - **Tuberculosis** and **leprosy**

 - **Diphtheria:** causes infection of the upper respiratory tract. In
   severe cases, this may lead to breathing difficulties and death.

 - **Tetanus:** causes rigid muscles and painful muscle spasms and can be
   deadly.

 - **Pertussis or whooping cough:** affects the respiratory tract and can
   cause a cough that lasts 4-8 weeks. The disease is very dangerous in
   infants.

 - **Measles:** can be a major cause of malnutrition, poor mental
   development, and hearing and visual impairments. Signs a child has
   measles are a fever and rash, together with a cough, a runny nose or
   red eyes. A child can die from measles.

 - **Polio:** signs of polio are a floppy limb or the inability to move. For
   every 200 children infected, one will be disabled for life.

 - **Hepatitis B:** in countries where hepatitis B is a problem, up to 10
   out of every 100 children will harbour the infection for life if they
   are not immunised with hepatitis B vaccine. Up to one quarter of
   children infected with hepatitis B may develop serious liver
   conditions such as cancer when they are older.

 - **Pneumonia:** pneumococcus bacteria or Haemophilus influenzae type B
   (Hib) bacteria is common and kills many young children. Either of
   these bacteria can also cause childhood meningitis and other serious
   infections. These bacteria are among the most dangerous for children,
   particularly those under 5 years old.

 - **Diarrhoea:** caused by rotavirus and can be severe. It affects nearly
   every child under age 5.

 - **Japanese encephalitis:** spread by mosquitoes, mainly in rural areas of
   Asian countries. It causes a severe illness, killing up to one third
   of those affected. Many survivors have brain damage. A trained health
   worker should be consulted for advice and information on national
   guidelines regarding use of this vaccine.
